notes:
1. Power Flow

In rotating machines (motors and generators), energy is converted between electrical and mechanical forms. This process is not 100% efficient due to various losses. The power flow diagram visualizes this:

Motor: Electrical Input $\rightarrow$ (Losses) $\rightarrow$ Mechanical Output (Shaft Power)

Generator: Mechanical Input $\rightarrow$ (Losses) $\rightarrow$ Electrical Output

2. Types of Losses

  • Copper Losses ($I^2R$): Heat generated in the windings (stator and rotor) due to electrical resistance.
  • Core (Iron) Losses: Occur in the magnetic core due to hysteresis and eddy currents.
  • Mechanical Losses: Friction in bearings and windage (air resistance) on the rotating parts.
  • Stray Load Losses: Minor losses not accounted for by the above categories.

3. Efficiency ($\eta$)

Efficiency is the ratio of useful output power to total input power.

$$ \eta = \frac{P_{out}}{P_{in}} = \frac{P_{out}}{P_{out} + P_{losses}} = \frac{P_{in} - P_{losses}}{P_{in}} $$

Mechanical power is related to torque ($T$) and angular velocity ($\omega$): $P_{mech} = T\omega$.

solvedExamples.question: A DC motor has an electrical input power of 5 kW. The copper losses are 300 W, core losses are 200 W, and mechanical losses are 100 W. What is the efficiency of the motor?
solvedExamples.explanation: Total losses = $300 + 200 + 100 = 600$ W = 0.6 kW. Output power = Input - Losses = $5 - 0.6 = 4.4$ kW. Efficiency $\eta = P_{out} / P_{in} = 4.4 / 5 = 0.88$ or 88%.

solvedExamples.question: A motor delivers 10 hp at the shaft with an efficiency of 85%. What is the electrical power input required in kW? (1 hp = 0.746 kW)
solvedExamples.explanation: First convert output power to kW: $P_{out} = 10 \text{ hp} \times 0.746 = 7.46$ kW. Then use the efficiency formula: $P_{in} = P_{out} / \eta = 7.46 / 0.85 \approx 8.776$ kW.
